Full text of "Annual Report"

See other formats 


This is a digital copy of a book that was preserved for generations on library shelves before it was carefully scanned by Google as part of a project 
to make the world's books discoverable online. 

It has survived long enough for the copyright to expire and the book to enter the public domain. A public domain book is one that was never subject 
to copyright or whose legal copyright term has expired. Whether a book is in the public domain may vary country to country. Public domain books 
are our gateways to the past, representing a wealth of history, culture and knowledge that's often difficult to discover. 

Marks, notations and other marginalia present in the original volume will appear in this file - a reminder of this book's long journey from the 
publisher to a library and finally to you. 

Usage guidelines 

Google is proud to partner with libraries to digitize public domain materials and make them widely accessible. Public domain books belong to the 
public and we are merely their custodians. Nevertheless, this work is expensive, so in order to keep providing this resource, we have taken steps to 
prevent abuse by commercial parties, including placing technical restrictions on automated querying. 

We also ask that you: 

+ Make non-commercial use of the files We designed Google Book Search for use by individuals, and we request that you use these files for 
personal, non-commercial purposes. 

+ Refrain from automated querying Do not send automated queries of any sort to Google's system: If you are conducting research on machine 
translation, optical character recognition or other areas where access to a large amount of text is helpful, please contact us. We encourage the 
use of public domain materials for these purposes and may be able to help. 

+ Maintain attribution The Google "watermark" you see on each file is essential for informing people about this project and helping them find 
additional materials through Google Book Search. Please do not remove it. 

+ Keep it legal Whatever your use, remember that you are responsible for ensuring that what you are doing is legal. Do not assume that just 
because we believe a book is in the public domain for users in the United States, that the work is also in the public domain for users in other 
countries. Whether a book is still in copyright varies from country to country, and we can't offer guidance on whether any specific use of 
any specific book is allowed. Please do not assume that a book's appearance in Google Book Search means it can be used in any manner 
anywhere in the world. Copyright infringement liability can be quite severe. 

About Google Book Search 

Google's mission is to organize the world's information and to make it universally accessible and useful. Google Book Search helps readers 
discover the world's books while helping authors and publishers reach new audiences. You can search through the full text of this book on the web 



at jhttp : //books . qooqle . com/ 



> 



ANNUAL REPORT 



OP THE 



Secretary of State 



TO THE 



GOVERNOR 



AND 



General Assembly of the State of Ohio 



FOB THE 



Year Ending June 30/1916 



Compiled by 

C Q. HILDEBRANT 

Secretary of State. 



Springfleli, Ohio: 

The Springfield PubMshing Company. 

State Printers. 

1916. 

Bound at the State Bindery. 



THE NEW YORK 
PUBLIC LIBRARY 

758989 

ASTOR. LENOX AND 
TILDEH FOUNDATIONS 
R 1918 L 



Office of the Secretary of State, 

Columbus, Ohio, July 20, 1916. 

To Ilis Excellency, Prank B. Willis, Governor of Ohio: 

fn compliance with the Constitution and the laws of Ohio, I have the 
Imnor to present to you, and through you, to the General Assembly of 
Ohio, the report of this department for the year ending June 30, 1916. 

Yours respectfully, 

0. Q. Hildebrant, Secretary o' State. 

(2) 



■ 






ANNUAL REPORT 

OP THE 

SECRETARY OF STATE 



The Department of State, for the year ending June 30, 1916, has filed 
and recorded 3,356 articles of incorporation of domestic corporations, and 
9,627 miscellaneous certificates relating to domestic corporations. 

In classification and number they are as follows : 

ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION. 

Banks — Commercial and Savings and Trust Companies 38 

Building and Loan Associations 33 

Cemetery Associations 7 

Churches and Church Societies _ .. . 91 

Colleges, Libraries and Literary Societies _ ... i 26 

Co-operative Companies _ . 6 

Electric Light and Power Companies «15 

Gas and Oil Companies.^ 79 

Heating Companies 8 

Insurance Companies and Associations. 11 

Manufacturing Companies . 846 

Mining Companies 69 

Printing and Publishing Companies _ 64 

Railroad Companies (steam) 5 

Street and Interurban Railway Companies 7 

Societies — Benevolent, Social and Mutual. .* 7 396 

Telephone and Telegraph Companies 10 

Real Estate Companies ." 369 

Companies — Various Purposes 1,276 

Total 3,356 

MISCELLANEOUS CERTIFICATES. 

Increase of Capital Stock J 718 

Reductions of Capital Stock 216 

Certificates of Subscription 2,452 

Railway Equipment Contracts 47 

Municipal Corporations 24 

Amendments, etc _ 144 

Certificates of Change of Name 276 

Certificates of Change of Location 16 

Dissolution of Domestic Corporations 722 

Cancellations on Order Tax Commission 5,012 

Total— 9,627 

(3)

filed and recorded as follows: 

State officers and appointees 20O 

Notaries Public Bonds (Act passed April 14, 1913) 3,565 

Total 3,765 

DOMESTIC CORPORATIONS— CAPITAL STOCK. 

The authorized capital stock of domestic corporations incorporated 
during the year ending June 30, 1916, was as follows : 

Banks— Commercial and Savings and Trust Companies $21,650,000 

"Building and Loan Associations _ 16,050,000 

Co-operative Companies 85,000 

Electric light and Power Companies— .- 296,000 

Gas and Oil Companies 6,301,000 

Heating Companies _ 96,000 

Manufacturing Companies 54,257,000 

Mining Companies 3,262,000 

Printing and Publishing Companies _ 1,242,000 

Railroad Companies (steam) 1,080,000 

Street and Interurban Railway Companies 584,500 

Real Estate Companies 13,840,200 

Telephone and Telegraph Companies 412,000 

Miscellaneous Companies (not included above) 39,774,000 

Total $158,929,700

The authorized increase of capital stock of domestic corporations 
during the year ending June 30, 1916, was as follows : 

Banks — Commercial and Savings and Trust Companies $1,298,500 

Building and Loan Associations... 37,555,000

FOREIGN CORPORATIONS. 

The .Department of State, during the year ending June 30, 1916, 
has filed the statements of, and has issued the certificates to do business 
in the state to 210 foreign corporations, and has filed 161 miscellaneous 
certificates relating to foreign corporations. In detail they are as follows : 

Statements under Section 178, General Code - 210 

Statements under Section 183, General Code 180 

Statements under Section 185, General Code 27 

Amendments of Articles of Incorporations 1 _.- 13 

Certificates of Appointment of Agents upon whom process may be served 46 

Reduction of Capital Stock 2 

Certificates of Retirement from Business in Ohio , 74 



Total 660 

THE RECEIPTS OF THE DEPARTMENT. 

The receipts of the Department of State for the year ending June 30, 
1916, amounted to the sum of $1,717,071.75, and were derived from corpo- 
ration initial fees, automobile license fees, and various miscellaneous 
sources. 

The receipts are shown more in detail by the following :

DISTRIBUTION QF COURT REPORTS. 

During the period from June 30, 1915, to June 30, 1916, the Departs 
raent received from The Excelsior Publishing Company, one hundred and 
eighty copies of Volume 90, Ohio State Reports, and one hundred and 
fifty copies of Volume 2, Ohio Appellate Court Reports ; also from the 
Fred J. Heer Printing Company, three hundred and fifty copies of 
Volume 91, and three hundred and forty-nine copies of Volume 92, Ohio 
State Reports, and three hundred and fifty copies of Volume 3, and three 
hundred and fifty copies of Volume 4, Ohio Appellate Court Reports. 
Distribution of Volume 90, Ohio State Reports, was made as follows : 

The Secretary of State, 1 copy. 

Law Library, Supreme Court, 1 copy. 

Attorney General, 5 copies. 

Law Library, 25 copies. 

Columbus Law Library, 1 copy. 

Superintendent Public Instruction, 1 copy. 

Industrial Commission, 1 copy. 

The Clerks of Courts of each county in the state, 88 copies. 

State Library, 1 copy. 

The Municipal Court, Cleveland, 1 copy. 

St. Johns University, Toledo, 1 copy. 

Auditor of State, 1 copy. 



SECRETARY OF STATE. 

Law Library, 15 copies. 
Ohio Northern University, 2 copies. 
Municipal Court, Cleveland, 1 copy. 
Clerk of U. S. Court, Toledo, 1 copy. 
E. 0. Randall, 2 copies.

O. S. U. Library, 10 copies.

St. Johns University, Toledo, 1 copy. 

Auditor of State, 1 copy.

Public Utilities Commission, 1 copy.

Volume 92.

Distribution of other reports was made as follows: 
One copy of Volume 88 to St. Johns University, Toledo; 1 copy of 
Volume 88 to Bureau of Inspection and Supervision of Public Offices.

STATIONERY ACCOUNT. 113 

STATIONERY DISBURSEMENTS. 
From June 30, 1915, to July 1, 1916. 

The distribution of stationery and supplies together with the number of units 
and the value thereof to the General Assembly, the various departments, boards 
and commissions of the state* of Ohio, by the stationery division of the department 
of state for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1916, was as follows: 

Pencils, 2,368 dozen, value $753.25; soap, 3,573 units, value $259.84; tablets, 
327 dozen, value $234.19; rubber bands, 624 units, value $223.97; typewriter paper, 
3,671 units, value $2,891.21; brooms and mops, 262 units, value $79.28; carbon 
paper, 1,118 units, value $918.96; typewriter ribbons, 24, value $10.00; paper fasten- 
ers, 3,481 units, value $271.29; pins, 126 units, value $75.39; file boxes, 2.090 units, 
value $318.60; note paper, 5 units, value $1.90; toilet paper, 588 units, value 
$35.20; envelope openers, 60 units, value $35.20; feather dusters 44 units value 
S3 1.80; book weights, 46 units, value $5.10; manuscript cover, 127 units, value 
$48.80; bill clips, 9 units, value $3.26; dust pans, 3 units, value $0.42; eye shades, 
72 units, value $4.48; ruling pens, 12 units, value $3.24; envelopes, 2,125 units value 
$3.30,; seal wafers 29,900 units, value $111.54; files stick, 16 units, value $0.92; 
presses, 12 units, value $20.20; stamp moisteners, 7 units, value $5.40; scissors and 
shears, 134 units, value $70.47; rubber erasers, 247 dozen, value $81.54; steel 
erasers, 246 units, value $110.95; ink, 380 units, value $170.06; mucilage and paste, 
439 units, value $96.29; sponges, 651 units, $142.52; sponge cups, 149 units, value 
$9.03; twine, 2,316 units, value $252.25; pens, 241 units, value $144.53; pen holders 
128 dozen, value $44.04; blotting paper, 4,447 units, value $91.87; blank books, 198 
units, value $60.03; impression books, 18 units, value $22.90; ink wells, 198 units, 
value $91.34; ink racks, 18 units, value $0.90; chamois, '83 units, value $22.78; 
rulers, 139 units, value $13.52; baskets, 97 units, value $42.61; brushes, 33 units, 
value $1.96; buckets, 42 units, value $19.81; tape, 61 units, value $10.82; tumblers, 
123 units, value $3.69; typewriter oil, 58 units, value $8.25; wire trays, 96 units, 
value $11.03; stamp pads, 26 units, value $4.76; drinking cups, 22,000 units, value 
$38.30. Total value of all stationery and supplies disbursed for the year $7,889.56.

Allen Trimble. 

William W. Irvin. 


60.008 

c 



♦From 1803 to 1850 the Secretary of State was elected by the General Assembly. 

IThe Democrat party of today claims lineal descent from the first Republican party, with President 
Jefferson as its founder. Authorities differ as to the date when the party dropped the name Repiublcan 
and assumed that of Democrat, it being ascribed to various dates between 1808 and 1820. 

t Political parties were disorganized at the time of the election of John 0- Adams. He claimed to 
be a Republican, as Jefferson, but his doctrines were decidedly FederaUstic. The opposition to his ad- 
ministration took the name of Democrat, and elected Jackson President in 1828. 



ELECTION STATISTICS FOB I915. 



233

received.

♦Since the census report of 1910, the city of 
Cincinnati has been redistricted, the townships in 
Hamilton County have been changed, and other 
substantial changes in territory, so that practical 
comparative population figures in these districts 
cannot be given.

♦Since the report of the census of 1910, the city 
of Cleveland has been redistricted, the townships in 
Cuyahoga County have been changed and other 
substantial changes made by the annexation of 
territory to the city of Cleveland, so that practical 
comparative population figures in the subdivisions 
ot these districts cannot be given.

UNITED STATES COURT OF CUSTOMS APPEALS. 

Constituted under Act of Congress approved August 5. 1909. 
Present address (temporary), 1415 H street, Northwest, Washington, D. C.

Thomas H. Clark 


Stenographic Reporter 


2.500 









DUTIES OF THE COURT. 

Decisions of contested cases in the collection of customs duties have been in great confusion for several 
years^ It has been exceedingly difficult for the law officers of the Government to obtain consistent inter- 
pretations of the various provisions of the tariff law as applied to specific articles. It is believed that by 
concentrating the responsibility for deciding such cases in a single judicial body much of the confusion 
that arises from these variations of interpretation will be removed. The new court will decide all con- 
tested cases without appeal, except on questions of constitutionality. 



292 STATISTICAL REPORT OF SECRETARY OP STATE.

Cincinnati, Ohio.,...- 

Cincinnati Ohio—-. .. 












The United States Marshal for the Southern District of Ohio performs the duties of marshal of the 
court. 

The salary of Circuit Judges is $7,000. 

TERMS OP COURT: ALL SESSIONS OF THE COURT SHALL BE HELD AT 
CINCINNATI UNLESS OTHERWISE SPECIALLY ORDERED BY THE COURT. 

One term of this court shall be held annually on the Tuesday after the first Monday of October* and 
adjourned sessions on the Tuesday after the first Monday of each other month in the year except August 
and September. At the July session no causes will be heard/, except upon special order of the court. 

A printed docket containing all cases docketed and not heard shall be made by the clerk for the 
October, January and April sessions.
